C. The PP test incorporates an automatic correction for autocorrelated residuals in the test regression

Answer:
response:
The main difference between the Dickey-Fuller (DF) and Phillips-Perron (PP) approaches to unit root testing is that the PP test incorporates an automatic correction for autocorrelated residuals in the test regression.

The DF test is a single equation approach to unit root testing, which tests the null hypothesis that a time series has a unit root. The alternative hypothesis is that the time series is stationary. The DF test uses a regression analysis to test the null hypothesis, and the test statistic is the t-statistic of the regression.

The PP test is a systems approach to unit root testing, which tests the null hypothesis that a time series has a unit root. The alternative hypothesis is that the time series is not stationary. The PP test uses a regression analysis to test the null hypothesis, and the test statistic is the t-statistic of the regression. The PP test also incorporates an automatic correction for autocorrelated residuals in the test regression, which makes it more powerful than the DF test in small samples.

The break-even point is also the point at which the business is most likely to be able to expand its operations, because it is the point at which the business is most likely to have enough money to invest in new equipment or to hire more employees. response:
